text: fills the screen, twenty-one years old, pensive, pretty. Camera lingers on her in CLOSE UP, noticing details: hair worn stylishly messy, no makeup, double-pierced ears (tho no earrings today), the corner of her bottom lip a little frayed where she's been chewing it ruminatively. She's the kind of beauty who can withstand such bad light institutional lighting, florescents HUMMING overhead, joi the chorus of ambient noises: a COUGH, papers RUSTLING, t SCRIBBLE of a pen, someone SHIFTING in their chair, etc. shot lingers until it becomes uncomfortable, invasive, scrutinizing this unhappy girl in an unguarded moment, th A new sound breaks her reverie, a muted BUZZING o.s., and eyes cut down to -
skittering sideways across the closed cover of her blue f exam book, like a bug. She has an INCOMING TEXT MESSAGE.
Our GIRL is just one of two hundred other STUDENTS fillin big auditorium-style lecture hall. Around her, classmates sit grim-faced, scribbling to beat the clock.
OUR GIRL traps the buzzing cellphone before it skitters r off the edge of the half-desk, looks at the display.
u done?!
Our girl leans back a little in her seat, gives a little to her friend seated across the lecture hall. Types a rep
WIND CHILL - Yellow Revisions 2/23/05
yes
She looks down as her friend text-messages: how r u getting home?
Typing. bus
She sends the message, a moment later the reply appears: sux 4 U
She glances up, sees her friend shoot her a sympathetic l

That's it, people! Wrap it up! There's a collective GROAN and the sound of two hundred panicked asses twisting in their seats. Our girl feels her phone buzz, looks down to see a final message from her friend: y don't u check the ride board?
A slow smile lights up her face at the idea, as all aroun her students rise and begin stampeding out. PROCTOR (O.S.) (cont'd) (shouting to be heard)
Test results will be posted on the Philosophy Department's web site in two weeks... Enjoy your break and have a Happy New Year. She gathers her things, begins to make her way down the stairs when -
Hey! - she's JOSTLED from behind by a CLASSMATE bolting past h She hands in her exam book, waves to her friend, and exit WIND CHILL - Yellow Revisions 2/23/05

Campus is a ghost town, most students having already left the holidays: the DORMS abandoned, the LIBRARY STACKS emp the LABS silent, the DINING HALLS eerie. Our GIRL hurries across the deserted college green dotted with little hillocks of snow from an earlier storm. She passes a forlorn pine tree decorated with CHRISTMAS LIGHT on her way to...

She arrives at a large, partially-enclosed KIOSK covered dozens of student-made notices, printed in a rainbow of e catching computer fonts and colors. A sign at the top rea RIDE BOARD. She scans the posted notices. One catches her eye: torn hastily from a spiral notebook, on which is scrawled a handwritten message: NE1 Need a Ride 2 Delaware 12/23? Call 607-154-9835
A gust of wind riffles the notice.

Our girl wheels her suitcase across a largely-empty parki lot. It's late afternoon, and already dark enough for the sodium vapor streetlights to have come on. A few snowflak swirl in their sickbed glow. We follow her to... A beat-to-shit 1988 OLDSMOBILE idling in the middle of th lot. An unbroken dusting of snow indicates it's been the only vehicle here for some time.
WIND CHILL - Yellow Revisions 2/23/05                   4

An underclassman GUY, 19, is asleep behind the wheel of t Oldsmobile. He's skinny, dressed in thrift-shop clothes, the complexion of someone who doesn't get out in the sun much. His car is filled with all of his earthly possessio books, CD's in plastic milk crates, dirty laundry, etc. She knocks on the driver's side window, startling him awa He stirs, blinks uncomprehendingly at the empty parking l GIRL
Do you think you could have parked any further from the entrance? The sight of her quickly snaps him awake.   He scrambles GUY (still a little groggy)
There were still cars when I got here. I thought we were going to get an early start to stay ahead of the snow? GIRL
What time is it? GUY
Quarter past three.
WIND CHILL - Yellow Revisions 2/23/05
GIRL

I'm two hours late?! Shit. Sorry. You should've just left without me. That's what I would've done. Hurry up and pop the trunk so I can stow my shit. He does. She walks back to the trunk, which is stuffed to capacity with more of his things: CLOTHES, a bag of GROCERIES, etc GIRL (cont'd) (calling to him)
Jesus, I'm just going home for Christmas. What are you doing? Pulling up stakes and movin' your Oakie family to Californey? She starts rearranging the trunk, making room for her bag GUY
I'm kinda getting kicked out of my apartment. I didn't have time to find someplace new before exams. She takes out some of his things.   Puts them on the grou GUY (cont'd)
Here, let me help you with that- GIRL
Why don't you just get the engine started and put the heat on? I can handle this. He watches her rearrange his things, a little flummoxed. GIRL (cont'd) (smiling)

Well? What are you waiting for? I thought you wanted to stay ahead of the snow? He hurries back to the driver's seat.   Starts the engine She hurriedly crams everything back in and slams the trun Then runs around to the passenger side and pulls on the d handle. Stuck.
WIND CHILL - Yellow Revisions 2/23/05
Now it's her turn to look impatient. She jerks on the han again, until he leans over to open the door from the insi
Sorry... it sticks.
She rolls her eyes, climbs in.
She climbs in, tries to power her window all the way to t top. It keeps getting stuck, leaving a half-inch gap. She shoots him a look: "What the hell?"
That's as far as it goes.   Sorry.
She rolls her eyes, never once interrupting her phone conversation. He puts the car in gear and they set out on their six hou roadtrip.
As they drive off, reveal: a forgotten bag of GROCERIES, still sitting on the ground.
They leave campus.   He eavesdrops as she rattles on.
(on her cell) Where are you? (listens) No, we're just rolling out... (listens) ... Believe me, I tried, but I couldn't get a flight. It's my own fault for waiting `til the last minute...
WIND CHILL - Yellow Revisions 2/23/05                  7.
She looks out at the passing landscape as they cruise sou on the interstate. The road is wet, though the snow hasn' yet started to stick. GIRL (laughs; on her cell)

What, are you kidding? I'm bored to tears... No, we're still on the highway... how should I know, all highways look exactly alike. She looks up, catches him shooting irritated looks her wa GIRL (cont'd)
What? GUY
You going to be on that thing the whole- He doesn't finish the thought, just chokes back whatever was about to say. Focuses on the highway ahead.
WIND CHILL - Yellow Revisions 2/23/05                  8.
GIRL (on her cell)
Uh oh, somebody's upset. I better call you back. (pause)

Who do you think? Ride Board Guy. Okay, `bye. She hangs up, aims the camera phone lens his way, and sna another digital picture of him. She puts the cellphone away, looks up to see him glaring her. GIRL (cont'd)
What? GUY (blurting)
This isn't cool. If I have to drive, you have to talk to me. GIRL
What, I'm the in-flight entertainment? GUY
That's how this ride-sharing thing works. Division of labor. We split everything fifty-fifty... Get it? GIRL
I've got news for you, I don't get much more entertaining than when I'm on the phone. He darkens, mutters under his breath: GUY (sarcastic)
This is turning out great. GIRL
What's that mean?
Forget it. They ride in silence for a moment. She tries to strike up conversation, by way of extending an olive branch.
WIND CHILL - Yellow Revisions 2/23/05                  9.
GIRL
So you're from Wilmington, huh? GUY
Yeah. GIRL
Where'd you go to school? GUY (falters for a second)
Um... Saint Vitus Academy. GIRL
St. Vitus? You're making that up. GUY
You're acquainted with every school in the area? GIRL
Pretty much, yeah. GUY
Including all the Catholic ones? Because that's where I went. Saint Vitus Academy for Catholic Boys. GIRL
Okay, fine... They drive for a few moments in silence. GUY
We had a class together, you know. GIRL
Huh? GUY
Intro to Modern Philosophy. He looks at her expectantly, as if she should remember hi
What? There were about a million people in that class. It was like Woodstock. Did you ever see so many Eastern religion types? (then)
So, what's your major?
WIND CHILL - Yellow Revisions 2/23/05                   1
GUY
Eastern religions. She hoots with laughter. But he's not kidding.   He seems surprised by her response. GUY (cont'd)
You aren't majoring in philosophy?
No. Why? GUY
I don't know. I just assumed... GIRL
Why would you assume anything about me? We just met. GUY (a little defensive)
I don't know... I guess you just... look like a philosophy major. GIRL
Try engineering. She enjoys the pained look of surprise on his face, lets twist for a second before explaining: GIRL (cont'd)
I only took Philosophy because I need a humanities credit. I heard it was an easy `A.' (then)
Hey, that reminds me. What'd you put for the extra credit question on the final? GUY
Nietzsche's theory of eternal recurrence. GIRL
Which is basically reincarnation, right? GUY
No, they're not really the same thing. Reincarnation is when you come back as something different and eternal recurrence is when you
WIND CHILL - Yellow Revisions 2/23/05
GUY (cont'd)
live the same life over and over again. He looks out at the road, reciting Nietzsche from memory: GUY (cont'd)
The eternal hourglass of existence is turned over and over, and you with it, a grain of dust. She looks at him as if he's nuts.   A beat, then: GIRL
He died of syphilis, you know. He stares grimly at the road ahead, biting back a comment GIRL (cont'd)
High school and philosophy. Pretty much covers everything, don't you think? Guess that concludes the entertainment portion of today's flight. She turns on the radio, finds a station with Christmas mu
The Oldsmobile passes slower-moving VEHICLES and zooms by Its interior light is on.

Her bare feet are propped on the dash, as she removes the nail polish. Widen. She's turned the front seat into a nail salon. Cotton balls, emery boards, bottles of clear and colored varnish are strewn everywhere. She picks a bottle, opens it, begins painting her nails.
WIND CHILL - Yellow Revisions 2/23/05
GIRL (concentrating)
Next gas station you see, do me a favor and pull over. I gotta pee. GUY
Okay, I'll keep my eyes peeled. She looks up from her feet, giving him a funny look. GUY (cont'd)
What? GIRL (resumes painting)
That phrase. `Keeping your eyes peeled.' It's kind of creepy, if you think about it. GUY
Huh. Actually, yeah, it is sorta. His eyes linger on her freshly painted toes on the dashbo She catches him staring.   He blushes, embarrassed.   Say GUY (cont'd)
... Speaking of peeling eyeballs. Did you know that's how they do that corrective eye surgery? GIRL
They use a laser. GUY
Well, yeah, they do... But there's definitely peeling involved too. I saw it on Discovery Health. If more people knew about the peeling part they might think twice before going under the knife. GIRL
Laser. GUY
Right, laser. GIRL
I'm having corrective eye surgery over the break.
WIND CHILL - Yellow Revisions 2/23/05
GUY
Oh. An awkward beat. GIRL
It's okay. I'm not really worried. GUY
Why? GIRL
I'm not worried? GUY
You're getting it done... GIRL
Because I hate wearing glasses. GUY
But they look good on you. She frowns. GIRL
How do you know? I don't wear them outside my dorm. He gets a cornered look. GUY
You sure? You never... to class or anything? Because I could swear I- GIRL
Never. GUY
Huh. Weird. I wonder why I thought- He breaks off, saved by the sight of a gas station up ahe GUY (cont'd)
Hey, look! Here's your gas station! She looks at him across the dark front seat, suspicious. WIND CHILL - Yellow Revisions 2/23/05
A florescent oasis in the gathering dark. A tow truck and several old wrecks rusting in the weeds surrounding it. The Oldsmobile pulls off the highway and up to a gas pump
He starts the pump.   Notices her still seated in the car He knocks on her window.    She opens the door. GUY
I thought you had to pee? GIRL
I didn't expect us to find a bathroom so soon. My nails aren't dry.
Oh. He looks over the roof of the car, sizing up the distance across the slushy parking lot. GUY (cont'd)
Well if you want, I can carry you. GIRL
That's okay, they'll be dry in just a second. GUY
Come on, I'm good at this... GIRL
You are not carrying me inside. He opens her door, pulls her legs around, and crouches do between them.
Hold on. GIRL
What are you doing?! Wait -
WIND CHILL - Yellow Revisions 2/23/05                   1
Suddenly he's rising and she throws her arms instinctivel around his neck. Unsettling as the deeply-weird moment is, she decides it' best to just humor him. But first - GIRL (cont'd)
I need my purse. He crouches a little so she can reach to retrieve it.
The door JINGLES as he enters, carrying her.   His face i from effort, hers from embarrassment. GIRL
Thanks. GUY
Sure. He just stands there.   She taps him on the shoulder. GIRL
You can let me down now. GUY

Okay. He crouches so she can slide off. She gives him a look, slips on the pair of flip-flops she's brought with her, t heads off in search of the ladies bathroom. Meanwhile, our guy saunters up toward the front of the convenience store. He nods to the twitchy CLERK, 20s, engrossed in a tattoo fetish magazine behind the counter.

The toilet is gross, tiled a queasy green, graffiti-cover Our girl finishes peeing, gets up from the toilet, uses h foot to flush and her elbow to turn on the faucet. She washes her hands, holding them under the automatic dryer. Broken. She wipes her hands dry on her jeans. Is about to exit wh she catches sight of her reflection in the dirty mirror.
WIND CHILL - Yellow Revisions 2/23/05                   1
On impulse she takes out her glasses from her purse.   Sl them on. Checks herself out in the mirror. Cool? Sexy? With her glasses on she notices something scratched into dirty mirror.
Where we see: "J.C.R. 12-24-88 R.I.P."

She frowns, slips her glasses back in their case and move exit. But when she grips the doorknob she finds it LOCKED She frowns. Rattles the doorknob a few times. A look of panic crosses her face, and she starts rattling doorknob harder. Did someone lock her in? Suddenly the doorknob comes off in her hand. She pounds on the door with the heel of her palm, shouts:

head_text.subj: HEY. HEY, I'M LOCKED IN HERE

text: Nothing. She turns, scanning the filthy bathroom, notices somethin
A VENT above the sink, near the ceiling.

She puts a foot up into the sink, testing it to see if it take her weight. Then climbs up and straightens on wobbly legs, until her face is near the filthy dust-clogged vent GIRL (cont'd) (calling into vent)

Her voice ECHOES weirdly. When the echoes die down she he something from the vent that makes her scowl: LAUGHTER. A our guy and the clerk are having a good laugh at her expe Pissed off now, she climbs back down, and attacks the bro doorknob with renewed urgency.
WIND CHILL - Yellow Revisions 2/23/05
And finally succeeds in getting the door to open.
As she exits she sees the CLERK and our guy talking quiet as if they know one another. She hesitates for a second, spying on them around a display of chips. Suspicious.
She strides up as the guy pays for the gas and a couple bottles of water. GIRL
Didn't you hear me banging in there? GUY (startled; puzzled smile)
When? GIRL
You think it's funny? Me locked in? GUY
Locked in where? GIRL
You're telling me you didn't just hear me banging on the door? GUY
I don't know what you're- GIRL (cuts him off)
Forget it. Let's just get on the road. He gathers up the bottled water, heads toward the door. clerk calls to him: CLERK
Remember, highway's your best bet- GUY (dismissive)
Don't worry about it man, I got it all covered. She frowns, following him to the exit.
WIND CHILL - Yellow Revisions 2/23/05                  18
GIRL
Are we lost or something? GUY (quickly)
No, I've made this drive a million times. He holds the door for her, then follows her outside.
As they exit and start toward the car she offers him a twenty. He looks at the money, as if he's never seen U.S. currency before. GUY
What's that for? GIRL
My half of the gas.
Keep it. GIRL
What do you mean? Isn't that how ride-sharing works? -- We split everything fifty-fifty? GUY
I don't take money from friends. Since when are they friends? They separate, walking around to their respective sides o the car. She tries the passenger door handle, only to fin it stuck.
WIND CHILL - Yellow Revisions 2/23/05
She rolls her eyes, waits for him to open it from the ins
She stares out at the road ahead, lulled by the sound of windshield wipers sweeping snowflakes from side to side.
A nondescript exit comes up fast for a side road. Which wouldn't be cause for alarm or even interest except- He suddenly turns the wheel sharply, taking the exit.

The car veers off the interstate onto a much smaller two- road marked with a simple sign, paint-on-wood, faded to illegibility: Scenic Route 606. The tires crunch across an old chain which had once preve access to the road but is now half-buried in the snow. Attached to it is a diamond-shaped warning sign of a more modern vintage reading: Rough Road.
She falls against him, bracing herself against the dash.
What the hell are you doing!?
Scenic detour.
(panicking)
No way! Get back on the highway.
Relax, I checked it out on the map. It looks interesting.
WIND CHILL - Yellow Revisions 2/23/05
GIRL
I mean it, get back on the highway right now! This is not going to happen! He looks a little pissed she's questioning his judgment. GUY

Will you chill. It's a shortcut. We'll be back on the highway before you know it. Hard to argue with a shortcut... Nonetheless, she glances back with a look of trepidation THE BACK WINDOW at the highway receding into the distance

The Oldsmobile cruises by, the only car on the two-lane scenic highway. As it leaves FRAME camera PANS to the dead grass on the roadside where it finds a sad little SHRINE half-buried i the snow: two homemade crosses, candle stumps, a rotting stuffed bear, deflated Mylar balloons. Scrawled on the crosses are: Sean            Amanda Dec-24-03        Dec-24-03
She watches him suspiciously out of the corner of her eye His face is eerie in the green light of the dashboard. He scans the radio dial for something other than static. GUY
Not many radio stations out here. GIRL
We're in a valley. FM radio waves travel in a straight line. They can't penetrate big obstacles like hills. Try AM.
WIND CHILL - Yellow Revisions 2/23/05
GUY

Where were you when I was flunking freshman physics? He switches over to AM. Finds a low-wattage mountain stat broadcasting Bobby Helms' 1957 "Jingle Bell Rock." Then he drives in silence.   Still stewing over her most recent digs. GIRL
So... Does your family do the whole traditional Christmas thing? GUY
No, my grandparents are Dutch, so I was raised on salted licorice and Sinterklaas... GIRL
How's that different from the regular Santa Claus? GUY
Instead of the North Pole, he lives in Spain. And instead of elves he's got an enforcer named Black Pete. Basically he's like your Santa, only scarier.
Charming. GUY
What's your Christmas like? GIRL

My folks split my freshman year, so I spend the holidays racing between them. Two trees... two turkey dinners...two sets of presents to return for store credit. So normally I can deal, but this year mom decided to rent a condo at the beach. Which is like, what? Two hours away. GUY
I don't know. The beach can be sort of nice in the winter. Romantic. She gazes out the window at night overtaking the landscap
WIND CHILL - Yellow Revisions 2/23/05                   2
GIRL
So were you a Rehobeth beach family or Stone Harbor? GUY
Stone Harbor. GIRL
We always went to Rehobeth. Year in and year out... Jesus, I've never been more bored in my life. I was always so jealous of my friends who spent summers at the Jersey shore. GUY
Me too. She turns from the window to look at him, scowling. GIRL
Stone Harbor is the Jersey shore.
(evasive)
Hm? Oh, yeah, I know. What I meant was- GIRL
You aren't from Delaware, are you? GUY
Well, see, it's kind of complicated- GIRL
Who are you?!
I'm exactly who I said I was, am, it's just- GIRL
What the hell's going on here? GUY
Nothing's going on- GIRL

head_text.subj: WHAT THE HELL IS GOING ON HERE

text: GUY
Look, just calm down. I can explain-
WIND CHILL - Yellow Revisions 2/23/05
HEADLIGHTS suddenly appear up ahead, blindingly bright. GUY (cont'd)
What the hell? She turns to look ahead, momentarily forgetting their fig as the oncoming headlights cross the median into their la GIRL
You think he doesn't see us? GUY
How can he not?
From a high angle overlooking the road we watch the two c racing toward one another, headed on a collision course.
For the time being their fight has taken a back seat to t oncoming car playing chicken with them. GIRL
Pull over and let this asshole by. GUY

Over where? There's no shoulder. He's right. On the passenger side the road abuts a steep wooded hillside. Opposite that it drops off into a ravine They are both too distracted by the ONCOMING HEADLIGHTS t notice the Christmas SONG that's just come on the RADIO: Brenda Lee's 1958 hit "Rockin' Around the Christmas Tree. BRENDA LEE
Rockin' around, the Christmas tree, at the Christ-mas par-ty hop...
The distance between the SPEEDING CARS is closing rapidly
The kids faces go white in the glare of the oncoming ligh
WIND CHILL - Yellow Revisions 2/23/05
Mistletoe hung where you can see, Ev'ry couple tries to STOP. Rockin' around, the Christmas tree, have a happy hol-i-day... Later we'll have some pumpkin pie, and do some car- rol-ing...
The OTHER CAR continues barrelling toward the OLDSMOBILE. The game of chicken fast approaching the point of no retu BRENDA LEE
You will get a sen-ti-men-tal fee- ling when you hear... Voices singing "Let's be jolly, DECK the halls with boughs of holly"...
Relief turns to dread as they realize the other car isn't slowing. GIRL
He's not stopping!

Hold on! He jerks the wheel hard, sending the Oldsmobile fishtaili out of control. The OTHER CAR skids over a small bridge and drops out of sight. They spin out in the opposite direction. Skid off the roa and SLAM into a snowbank with a bone-shuddering CRASH. BRENDA LEE
Rockin' around, the Christmas tree, Have a happy hol-i-day. Everyone's dancing mer-ri-ly in the New. Old. Fash-ioned. Wa-a-ay!
WIND CHILL - Yellow Revisions 2/23/05
The Oldsmobile has ended up on the opposite roadside faci the wrong way, its driver's side jammed into a snowbank. Snow boils in its headlights.

The interior is dark. The girl has been thrown under the dash. It's hard to tel in this light whether she's still breathing. Finally she stirs, disoriented. She climbs back into her seat, piecing together where she It takes her a beat to remember him. She looks over slowl He's not moving, though thanks to his seatbelt he's still upright behind the wheel. His head rests limply against t driver's window, which now looks out on nothing but snowb A link of blood trickles down the glass. Dead? She's not taking any chances. Without a sound she slips i her shoes, coat. Gropes for her cellphone among the detri at her feet. Suddenly he stirs, groaning. She freezes. The seconds ticking by on the DASHBOARD CLOCK. When he doesn't wake, she resumes fumbling for her cell. Finds it.   Then eases open the creaky passenger door. And launches herself into the frigid night.
She hurries down the road away from the car. Breath cloud in the frigid air. Punches in numbers on her cell phone.
WIND CHILL - Yellow Revisions 2/23/05
No SIGNAL BARS. She's starting to freak now.   She hits the REDIAL button GIRL
... please... please... please... Suddenly, from behind -- GUY (O.S.)
What are you doing? She screams, spins around. He's standing right behind her, his face in silhouette. GIRL
C-Calling 9-1-1. Or trying to.
Any luck? GIRL (shakes head `no')
Can't... I can't get a signal here. He receives this news with a strange calm. GIRL (cont'd)
What about yours? GUY
I don't have a cell. GIRL
How can you not have a cell? GUY (ignoring her)
How're you doing? You all right? GIRL
I... yeah, I'm okay. Nothing broken... What about you? GUY
I don't know. Think I hit my head. He puts his hand to the left side of his skull and pushes it. Like someone testing a melon for ripeness. Come to think of it, his speech is a little wooden.
WIND CHILL - Yellow Revisions 2/23/05
She watches as he turns and takes a few aimless steps awa GUY (cont'd)
What happened to the, uh, the guy? GIRL
Who? GUY
Asshole who ran us off the road. She's completely forgotten all about the other vehicle un now. She turns to look, puzzled. There's no sign of the other vehicle anywhere. They're al GIRL
I don't know. I guess maybe he decided just to hit and run. GUY
So where are his tire tracks? She looks, sees an unbroken expanse of fresh white snow. GIRL
In case you haven't noticed, it's coming down pretty hard. GUY (points)

Yeah, but you can still see our tracks. The mystery of the missing tracks seems to have penetrate his post-accident fog, bringing him back into sharper foc She watches as he walks out in front of the Olds' headlig to the middle of the road, where the other vehicles track should be. GUY (cont'd)

What the hell?! He walks back to the Olds and opens the passenger door (t only access into or out of the stranded car, thanks to th snowbank). He begins searching the glove compartment for flashlight.
WIND CHILL - Yellow Revisions 2/23/05

Deliberating whether to seize this moment of distraction make a break for it. She looks back down the long dark road. Looks back at him bent over rummaging in the Oldsmobile. Too risky. Curiosity getting the better of her, she walks out to the middle of the road to have a look for herself. No tracks. Just an expanse of fresh powder and a few of his footprin
(to herself) This doesn't make any sense...

At that moment he emerges from the car with a flashlight. spokes it, sweeps the strong beam over their surroundings The left side of the road falls off into a darkness so de even the flashlight's beam can't penetrate it. A precipic He cups his hand and calls out at the top of his lungs.
(calling) HELLO!
She jumps at the sound of his voice, her nerves frazzled. GUY (cont'd) (calling) ANYBODY OUT THERE!? ANYONE?! HEY!
His voice is swallowed by the dark. After the echoes subs the only sound in the hush is the SIZZLE of falling snow a weird otherworldly HUM. He snaps off his flashlight, thrusts it into his coat poc
What now?
WIND CHILL - Yellow Revisions 2/23/05
GUY
I guess we see how bad we're stuck. They trudge back to the car, boots crunching in the snow. GUY (cont'd)

You steer, I'll push. He holds the passenger door for her while she scrambles i scooting over into the driver's seat. He leaves the door open so they can communicate. He walks back to the rear of the stranded Oldsmobile. He's pulling on gloves when something half-buried in the nearby catches his eye. He takes out the flashlight, shin it at the roadside. Little wooden crosses. Just two this time. Another sad shrine, to a different se of anonymous victims of Route 606. Their proximity to the stranded Olds obviously unsettles GIRL (calling)
Ready? He bends with a little wince and braces his shoulder agai the rear bumper. GUY (calling)

Ready! The tail lights come on as she turns the ignition.   He h her crank the starter motor. Cranking... cranking... cranking... Finally turning over. She slips the Oldsmobile in gear, and he starts pushing. The rear tires spin, throwing slush; but car won't budge. GUY (cont'd) (calling)
Give it more gas! She floors it; the tires SCREAMING.
WIND CHILL - Yellow Revisions 2/23/05

He puts everything he's got into pushing, but it's no use Suddenly his face contorts in pain and he clutches his si He drops out of view, disappearing in a cloud of red exha A beat later he pulls himself up, pounds on the trunk. GUY (cont'd) Stop!
The tires stop spinning.

She's sitting in the driver's seat of the idling car when hears the crunch-crunch-crunch of his approaching footste In that moment she makes a decision. Scrambles across the front seat, pulls the door shut hard
He arrives at the passenger side door handle just as the power locks all go THUNK. He's locked out.
Hey, open up.
He tugs at the handle a few times.      Knocks on the win GUY (cont'd) You wanna pop the locks?

But it's no use. She stops trying to keep up and pauses briefly, devastated, catching her breath. Then she pushes in the direction he went.

It's almost light out now, and SHE'S ALONE, staggering al the road as quickly as her exhausted state allows. It's l running in a dream, never fast enough to outdistance an unseen pursuer. But then she hears it - THE HIGHWAY. She can't believe she's made it back to civilization.

The gas pumps are crowded with EMERGENCY VEHICLES and PERSONNEL. The morning calm is broken by the BEEP BEEP BE of trucks backing up, the BLEET of arriving ambulances, t constant CHATTER of two-way radios.
